body:
Received an email from a friend with just single link in the body

http://derbor.com/fvwd/fox_newsx.php

Which if you open with a desktop forwards you to http://com-zg88.net/indexer.php?a=298712&c=wl_con&s=18f and then to http://womenshealth.com-zg88.net/diet/report-us/

But if opened on mobile phone, you are forwarded to http://mobile.downloadmobilessoftware.ru/FLVupdate.php and commonly, start downloading a file rightaway Security.Update.apk

Most US Android devices however, by default disallow installation of applications from sources other than Google Play and so we promptly delete the file.

It is mildly interesting however, how this whole scam works.

Let's try with to play with curl

$ curl http://mobile.downloadmobilessoftware.ru/FLVupdate.php

<html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.top.location=document.URL.replace("FLVupdate.php","FLVupdate2.php");
</script>
</head><body></body></html>

Looks like a simple URL rewrite, try again.

$ curl http://mobile.downloadmobilessoftware.ru/FLVupdate2.php

Empty. Faking Nexus 5 user agent...

$ curl -A "Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 4.4; Nexus 5 Build/KRT16M) \
AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/4.0 \
Chrome/30.0.0.0 Mobile Safari/537.36" \
http://mobile.downloadmobilessoftware.ru/FLVupdate2.php > Security.Update.apk

... and we've got us that file.

I haven't tried disassembling it yet, but based on Russian download URL it seems interesting. Here it is with extensions changed to .txt if someone is interested.

Security.Update.txt
